awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Control of Broadband Acoustic-caused Vibration at Nanoscale: An Enabling Technology for Cleanroom Metrology
awd_abstract_narration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project aims to create a suite of dynamics and control tools to understand and combat acoustic-caused mechanical vibrations at nanoscale in atomic force microscope (AFM), a well-known and unique instrument used for studying objects at fractions of nano-meter scale. Specifically, the objective is to eliminate the acoustic caused vibrations of the AFM probe to enhance the instrument's accuracy and efficiency. Success of this research will enable AFM to achieve sub-nanometer metrological accuracy in cleanroom environment, thereby, contributing to ensure the fabrication quality of next-generation nano-/micro-fabrication in semiconductor industry. The knowledge and techniques learned in this work can be readily used in other scanning probe applications such as scanning electronic microscope and laser annular detector. The resulting control tools for combatting acoustic-caused probe vibration will also broaden the implementations of AFM in other emerging applications; for example, it will allow researchers to combine AFM with other instruments such as optical tweezer and optical microscope to enable multi-function measurement and manipulation of live biological samples. The educational activities of the project include summer internships for students, curriculum course module development, recruitment and retention activities for under-represented students, and outreach to K-12. 

The project is motivated by the need for eliminating acoustic-caused mechanical vibrations to enable high level of accuracy and speed in sub-nanometer measurement and calibration in cleanroom environment. The specific research goals include: creating a data-driven, robust approach to accurately estimate and predict the noise-caused probe vibration, creating a data-driven feedforward-feedback control approach with online iterative adaptation to cancel the acoustic-caused probe vibration, analyzing the convergence and robustness of the proposed modeling and vibration estimation, and the convergence and performance of the proposed data-driven feedforward-feedback control, and experimentally implementing, testing, and validating the proposed approach. The testing and validation will take place for general-purpose AFM as well as semiconductor-AFM at both facilities -- in the laboratory at Rutgers University and in laboratory facilities at Bruker, the participating industry.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes in intellectual merits include the following aspects:

1. Through the support of this project, the team successfully created  methodologies for post filtering to remove acoustic-noise-caused distortions in scanning probe microscope (SPM) images, with the following novel features:

  • The effect of noise from an unknown and arbitrary location is accounted for. 
  • A data-driven approach is created to use the measured data directly to constructed the filter. The technique is robust against disturbances and variations in the system behavior without the usual trade-off to performance loss as commonly seen in parameterized-model-based techniques. 
  • The unknown noise location effect has been accounted for by developing a noise localization method based on phase difference (time delay) measurement and integrating it to a dictionary-based approach that consists of an array of acoustic dynamics responses and an array of acoustic noise propagation dynamics. 
  • A gradient-based coherence minimization technique was created to optimize the FIR filter. The gradient-based technique was developed to iteratively minimize the coherence between the noise and the noise-effected image signals, which in turn, minimizes the residual noise distortion in the SPM image measured. 

2. The data-driven optimal acoustic-noise filtering technique created above has been successfully implemented and demonstrated through SPM imaging results. Two types of samples including a silicon wafer and a calibration sample have been imaged using SPM tapping-mode, with or without acoustic noise induced into the environment. The obtained images were filtered by using the data-driven filtering technique and the conventional bandstop filtering method. The experimental results showed that

  • The acoustic dynamics of the unknown-location noise can be accurately estimated by using the Dictionary-based method. The estimated acoustic dynamics was close to the directly measured one (with the sensor—a microphone—placed at the noise source location) with the difference less than 10%.
  • The acoustic-noise-caused distortion to the SPM images obtained were dramatically reduced by using the data-driven optimal filtering technique. The image distortion was reduced by over 80% for both types of samples, while the sample topography features were preserved in the filtered image. On the contrary, the acoustic-caused image distortion was only reduced by less than 30% when using the conventional bandstop filter, and the sample topography was smeared. 

3. The team extended the above filtering technique and created an online active acoustic noise cancellation technique for AFM imaging, by extending the adaptive filtering technique with the following innovations:

  • A Kalman-filter based method was developed to estimate and decouple acoustic-noise-caused cantilever vibration from that due to the sample topography. Unlike in common acoustic noise cancellations where the residual acoustic noise can be directly measured, in SPM imaging the residual noise-caused vibration is coupled and mixed with the sample topography effect. 
  • The convergence of the adaptive filter was accelerated by employing an a priori measured acoustic dynamics response as the initial choice of the filter. 
  • The adaptive filter was further enhanced by using the estimated residual noise-caused SPM cantilever vibration in the least mean square algorithm to update the filter coefficient. 

4. The proposed method was implemented and demonstrated through SPM imaging experiments. A calibration sample was imaged under SPM contact-mode (the technique can be easily transferred to other imaging mode such as tapping-mode) when acoustic noise was induced into the environment. The images obtained was compared to those obtained without induced noise and without active noise cancellation. The comparison showed that the noise-caused image distortion can be significantly reduced by over 60%, and the technique worked well for noise with unknown and arbitrary location. 

6. An algorithm based on the compressed-sensing (CS) theory was developed for mobile sensing of a dynamic field. The algorithm determines the distribution of the measurement time between the chosen POIs such that (1). the full sequence (i.e., the dynamics) of the signal at each POI can be fully recovered from the intermittently measured data via the CS theory, (2). the mobile agent (i.e., sensor) can have enough time to transit between the POIs without missing the designated measurement time; and (3). the total travel distance of the mobile sensor and the total transition time are minimized. The issue of the spatial-temporal coupling issue (where the mobile sensor is required to measure at two POIs simultaneously or the transition time is too short—to meet the random requirement) was resolved through a check-and-removal process. Then the measurement scheme was further optimized through a simulated-annealing-based shuffle-and-pair process to minimize the distance and the time of transition. 

The outcomes in broader impact include:

1. The research outcomes have been disseminated to  scientific community through over 13 journal publications, of which 9 articles have been published. 

3. Three Ph.D. students have been partially supported by this project, of whom two have been successfully earned their degree. Four Master students have also been trained through this project, and two undergraduate students have been trained through the REU-supplement support of this project. 


Last Modified: 12/14/2021
Modified by: Qingze Zou

Images (1 of )
  • Comparison of AFM images (first row) of a silicon sample and (second row) of a calibration sample obtained: (a1,b1) with the induced acoustic noise, (a2,b2) with the acoustic noise filtered by the dynamics-based filtering, (a3,b3) filtered by the DD-DOF, and (a4, b4) without noise.
    Jiarong Chen, and Qingze Zou
    Copyrighted
    Qingze Zou
    Data-driven Optimal-dynamics-based filtering (DD-DOF of AFM images with comparison.
  • Comparison of the dynamic viscoelasticity obtained by the CS-based method to those obtained by using the sequential sensing method at three POIs (left column) and the corresponding errors (right column).
    Tianwei Li, and Qingze Zou
    Copyrighted
    Qingze Zou
    Compressed-sensing-based optimal mobile sensing of dynamics with comparison.
  • Comparison of (a) an acoustic-noise-effected AFM image of a calibration sample to (b) the filtered image obtained by using the DD-DOF technique, (c) the filtered image via a bandstop filter, and (d) the image without acoustic noise.
    Jiarong Chen, and Qingze Zou
    Copyrighted
    Qingze Zou
    Data-driven Dynamics-based Optimal Filter vs. Bandstop Filter
  • Comparison of (a) an acoustic-noise-effected atomic force microscope image of a calibration sample to (b) the filtered image obtained by using the online active acoustic noise cancellation technique, and (c) a reference image obtained without acoustic noise induced.
    Jiarong Chen, and Qingze Zou
    Copyrighted
    Qingze Zou
    Online active acoustic noise cancellation in atomic force microscope imaging
por.por_txt_cntn:
The outcomes in intellectual merits include the following aspects:
1. Through the support of this project, the team successfully created  methodologies for post filtering to remove acoustic-noise-caused distortions in scanning probe microscope (SPM) images, with the following novel features:

The effect of noise from an unknown and arbitrary location is accounted for. 
A data-driven approach is created to use the measured data directly to constructed the filter. The technique is robust against disturbances and variations in the system behavior without the usual trade-off to performance loss as commonly seen in parameterized-model-based techniques. 
The unknown noise location effect has been accounted for by developing a noise localization method based on phase difference (time delay) measurement and integrating it to a dictionary-based approach that consists of an array of acoustic dynamics responses and an array of acoustic noise propagation dynamics. 
A gradient-based coherence minimization technique was created to optimize the FIR filter. The gradient-based technique was developed to iteratively minimize the coherence between the noise and the noise-effected image signals, which in turn, minimizes the residual noise distortion in the SPM image measured. 

2. The data-driven optimal acoustic-noise filtering technique created above has been successfully implemented and demonstrated through SPM imaging results. Two types of samples including a silicon wafer and a calibration sample have been imaged using SPM tapping-mode, with or without acoustic noise induced into the environment. The obtained images were filtered by using the data-driven filtering technique and the conventional bandstop filtering method. The experimental results showed that

The acoustic dynamics of the unknown-location noise can be accurately estimated by using the Dictionary-based method. The estimated acoustic dynamics was close to the directly measured one (with the sensor—a microphone—placed at the noise source location) with the difference less than 10%.
The acoustic-noise-caused distortion to the SPM images obtained were dramatically reduced by using the data-driven optimal filtering technique. The image distortion was reduced by over 80% for both types of samples, while the sample topography features were preserved in the filtered image. On the contrary, the acoustic-caused image distortion was only reduced by less than 30% when using the conventional bandstop filter, and the sample topography was smeared. 

3. The team extended the above filtering technique and created an online active acoustic noise cancellation technique for AFM imaging, by extending the adaptive filtering technique with the following innovations:

A Kalman-filter based method was developed to estimate and decouple acoustic-noise-caused cantilever vibration from that due to the sample topography. Unlike in common acoustic noise cancellations where the residual acoustic noise can be directly measured, in SPM imaging the residual noise-caused vibration is coupled and mixed with the sample topography effect. 
The convergence of the adaptive filter was accelerated by employing an a priori measured acoustic dynamics response as the initial choice of the filter. 
The adaptive filter was further enhanced by using the estimated residual noise-caused SPM cantilever vibration in the least mean square algorithm to update the filter coefficient. 

4. The proposed method was implemented and demonstrated through SPM imaging experiments. A calibration sample was imaged under SPM contact-mode (the technique can be easily transferred to other imaging mode such as tapping-mode) when acoustic noise was induced into the environment. The images obtained was compared to those obtained without induced noise and without active noise cancellation. The comparison showed that the noise-caused image distortion can be significantly reduced by over 60%, and the technique worked well for noise with unknown and arbitrary location. 

6. An algorithm based on the compressed-sensing (CS) theory was developed for mobile sensing of a dynamic field. The algorithm determines the distribution of the measurement time between the chosen POIs such that (1). the full sequence (i.e., the dynamics) of the signal at each POI can be fully recovered from the intermittently measured data via the CS theory, (2). the mobile agent (i.e., sensor) can have enough time to transit between the POIs without missing the designated measurement time; and (3). the total travel distance of the mobile sensor and the total transition time are minimized. The issue of the spatial-temporal coupling issue (where the mobile sensor is required to measure at two POIs simultaneously or the transition time is too short—to meet the random requirement) was resolved through a check-and-removal process. Then the measurement scheme was further optimized through a simulated-annealing-based shuffle-and-pair process to minimize the distance and the time of transition. 


The outcomes in broader impact include:
1. The research outcomes have been disseminated to  scientific community through over 13 journal publications, of which 9 articles have been published. 
3. Three Ph.D. students have been partially supported by this project, of whom two have been successfully earned their degree. Four Master students have also been trained through this project, and two undergraduate students have been trained through the REU-supplement support of this project.
